intro: Abutilon johnsonii, commonly known as Johnson's abutilon, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a shrub or small tree that typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments. The plant features broad, heart-shaped leaves and produces showy, lantern-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, or red. It has a fibrous root system that helps it survive in dry conditions. The plant is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance and ornamental value.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon johnsonii is primarily native to the southern United States, specifically Texas and New Mexico. It is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions, growing in rocky soils and open habitats. This species thrives in environments with full sun and low moisture, making it well adapted to desert conditions. It is often seen in limestone hills and canyons, where it forms part of the local flora. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endemic plant in these regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon johnsonii was mainly introduced to Hawaii. It was introduced as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. The plant has since become naturalized in certain areas of the island. It is now considered an invasive species in some parts of Hawaii. Its spread has raised concerns due to its potential impact on native ecosystems.
